title: Embracing ugly veg and the ugly side of poultry production to make more profitable and sustainable products - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Reduced, a Copenhagen-based company, has joined forces with Caldic to explore and scale upcycled ingredients for the food industry in the Nordics and Baltic states. The collaboration has launched with a series of organic flavour enhancers based on side streams from the food industry, such as spent laying hens and wasted mushrooms. The flavour enhancers are distinguished by boosting the umami taste without containing additives, and have the potential to lower costs by enabling the creation of meat hybrids.
green_innovation: TRUE; The article describes an innovation that contributes to environmental sustainability goals by reducing food waste and using side streams from the food industry.
business_innovation: TRUE; The article describes a new product (organic flavour enhancers based on side streams from the food industry) that differs significantly from the firm's previous products.
green_product: TRUE; The article describes a product (organic flavour enhancers based on side streams from the food industry) that is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: TRUE; The article describes a process (controlling fermentation processes of side streams and generating flavours at accelerated production time) that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability.
product_or_process: Organic flavour enhancers based on side streams from the food industry
likely_naics_codes: ['311999: All Other Food Manufacturing', '311613: Roasted Nuts and Peanut Butter Manufacturing', '311919: Other Snack Food Manufacturing', '311823: Flour Milling']
greenwashing: FALSE; The article does not describe a product or process innovation that is an example of greenwashing.

title: TerraCycle takes recycling to a whole new level - Inhabitat
summary: TerraCycle offers drop-off locations for hard-to-recycle items like disposable cups, pet food bags and pouches, and beauty products. These items are then sent to Material Recovery Facilities where they are sorted by material makeup and sent to third party partners who process them into usable forms, which are then given new life in a variety of products. TerraCycle is constantly investing in the research and development of new recycling processes with the goal of converting waste into usable products at the highest level.
likely_naics_codes: ['562998 - All Other Miscellaneous Waste Management Services', '326199 - All Other Plastics Product Manufacturing', '322213 - Paperboard Mills', '322110 - Pulp Mills']

title: Australia's vegetable upcycling firm launches Nutri V goodies entering the snacking space - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: The article describes Nutri V, a company that produces vegetable powders and snacks from vegetables that would otherwise go to waste. The company's new product, Nutri V goodies, is a range of puffed snacks that contain two vegetable servings in each pack and are available in three flavors: salt and pepper pumpkin, cauliflower, and chilli and lime broccoli. Nutri V is also working on developing new products, including vegetable powder pouches, yoghurts, drinks, and enhanced pet foods.
green_innovation: TRUE. Nutri V's vegetable powders and snacks are green innovations because they reduce food waste and promote the use of sustainable farming practices.
business_innovation: TRUE. Nutri V's vegetable powder pouches and snacks are business innovations because they are new products that differ significantly from the company's previous products and have been introduced to the market.
green_product: TRUE. Nutri V's vegetable powders and snacks are green products because they are made from sustainably sourced vegetables and are designed to reduce food waste.
green_process: FALSE. The article does not describe a specific green process.

greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not provide any evidence that Nutri V's products or processes are an example of greenwashing.

title: Unwrapping Eco-Labels: What Do They Really Mean? - U.S. News & World Report
summary: This article provides information on several new eco-labels that are appearing on food and beverage packaging and restaurant menus to signify the environmental impact of different products. These labels, which often reflect greenhouse gas emissions or carbon spent throughout the entire journey of a food product, including production, distribution, preparation, and disposal, may help consumers make more climate-conscious choices. However, some believe that these labels may be confusing and misleading, and instead recommend focusing on reducing meat consumption, minimizing food waste, and paying attention to the regulated nutrition facts panel on the back of food packages.
green_innovation: TRUE, the article describes several new eco-labels that are appearing on food and beverage packaging and restaurant menus to signify the environmental impact of different products.
business_innovation: TRUE, the article describes several new eco-labels that are appearing on food and beverage packaging and restaurant menus. The labels, which often reflect greenhouse gas emissions or carbon spent throughout the entire journey of a food product, including production, distribution, preparation, and disposal, may help consumers make more climate-conscious choices.
green_product: TRUE, the article discusses eco-friendly food and beverage items that have been certified by organizations such as Carbonfund and Climate Neutral. These certified products are considered green because they have met certain environmental standards throughout their lifecycle, from ingredient sourcing and packaging to distribution, consumer use, and eventual disposal.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe any specific green processes.
product_or_process: eco-labels for food and beverage products

title: This engineer created a sustainable brand to upcycle waste fabric and clothes - YourStory
summary: Twirl.Store is a Kolkata-based company that collects unwanted clothing and fabric from individuals and organisations. A section of these are given to people in slums and villages for use. The rest of the material is upcycled into new products such as bags, accessories, and gift items, sold online and offline. All work is done by rural women. Twirl was founded in 2017 as an initiative to “reduce cloth wastage, encourage women empowerment, conserve natural resources like water, and meet the clothing needs of the less fortunate”.
green_innovation: TRUE, Twirl.Store's business model promotes sustainable practices by reducing textile waste, conserving natural resources, and empowering rural women through employment.
business_innovation: TRUE, Twirl.Store has developed a unique business model that combines social and environmental sustainability with a revenue-generating product line.
green_product: TRUE, Twirl.Store's upcycled products are made from recycled materials, reducing waste and conserving resources.
green_process: TRUE, Twirl.Store's upcycling process reduces waste and conserves resources by transforming unwanted textiles into new products.
product_or_process: Upcycling unwanted clothing and fabric into new products
likely_naics_codes: ['313311 - Broadwoven Fabric Mills', '315220 - Cut and Sew Apparel Manufacturing', '493190 - Other Warehousing and Storage', '562112 - Solid Waste Collection']
greenwashing: FALSE, Twirl.Store's business model and products are genuinely sustainable and environmentally friendly.

title: The Age of Food Delivery: The Issue of Plastic Overuse - 국민대학교
summary: The increased use of food delivery services during the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in plastic waste, prompting concerns about environmental pollution. While some restaurants in South Korea are exploring the use of multi-use containers, progress on reducing plastic use has been slow compared to other countries. The article highlights the importance of consumer habits and policy changes in promoting sustainable practices.

title: Top 10 Best Handicraft Companies In USA 2023 - Inventiva
summary: Handicraft companies are becoming increasingly popular in the United States due to rising demand for unique, sustainable products.  Online marketplaces and social media platforms have helped these companies reach a wider audience, and there are many craft companies offering custom orders and ready-made products. The future looks bright for the industry, with many companies expanding and consumers expecting more high-quality, unique products in the future.
